elements.text: Listen to the words in the title of this week’s story:
We learned that both of these words start with the /j/ sound. What letter does that sound start with?
I’m going to say two words that start with the same sound. Then we will think of as many words as we can that start with the same sound. Let’s see how many words we can think of!
Use the /j/ sound to model, and
as the words you are matching. Instruct children to jump in if they think of other words such as
Read aloud the two words you have decided on, such as “yellow yo-yo.” Then ask,
What sound do these words start with? What letter makes that sound?
Allow children two minutes to come up with as many words as they can that start with that sound. Provide guiding prompts as necessary to help children brainstorm.
Challenge children with an additional two minutes to think of as many words as they can that match the beginning sounds of “velvet vest.” Repeat with “queen’s quilt.”
Practice Writing Letters Yy, Vv, and Qq
Have children practice writing the letters
Next to each letter, ask them to draw a picture of something that reminds them of that sound.
Provide more guiding prompts such as “What do you put flowers in?” for the letter
or “What can we use to knit a scarf?” for
. Allow children more time to come up with words that start with letters
or focus on just one letter instead of all three.
Challenge children to come up with matching words on their own by having them or write or draw words that match the beginning sounds of
. Have children share their brainstormed words and ask their peers to determine the validity of each word.
is pronounced the same as the letter
in Spanish. In Spanish, the letter pairing
has the same sound as /k/. Take time as needed, to review the English phonemes /v/ and /qw/.

There are many reasons children may have delays in speech development; a range of hearing impairments may be responsible for some issues. Call attention to the beginning sound of the word. Model making the sound slowly while pointing to the letter. Ask them to follow along.

and talked about knowing what we’re good at and what scares us, like Jabari does.
Now we’re going to write and draw about ourselves! Just like Jabari knows what he’s good at and learns what scares him, we’re going to write about that, too!
Draw an activity that you’re good at, such as running, dancing, or drawing. I’m good at
What are you really good at?
Now I’m going to think of something I want to be better at. I’m going to draw
because I want to be better at
What would you like to be better at?
Have children draw what they’d like to be better at.
Now let’s think about something that scares us. Who remembers what Jabari was scared of? How did Jabari face his fear? Let’s draw one thing that scares us.
Talking about fears is a healthy activity but can potentially upset children, so pay attention to how children are feeling about the activity and be prepared to end the activity early if needed.
Facilitate a healthy discussion about what children feel that they are good at, what they’d like to be better at, and what scares them.

If children find it hard to self-analyze, mention examples of times you have seen them display a strength. Remind children that everyone has some skills they are good at and some that they need to work on. Everyone has different abilities and learns in different ways.

For an added challenge, have interested children interview a partner without your help, asking questions such as “What are you good at?” or “What do you want to be better at?” When children answer, have partners draw or write down what their partner says.

Review common activities that children participate in, such as running, dancing, singing, drawing, and different sports. Encourage multilingual learners to describe the activity with words they know and help them recall the correct verbs in English.

Learning self-awareness and ways to modify responses to the environment and others can help significantly with the self-control and impulsive issues that often accompany attention deficits. Talk to children about self-awareness and self-regulation, and explain that it extends to recognizing our feelings. Make faces to show emotions: happy, sad, mad, or scared. Ask children to identify the feeling. When they answer, ask them to name a time when they felt that emotion. If time permits, talk about how they react to these feelings.

Before class, place some objects in the middle of the rug, around which children will form a circle. You may also choose to use sleeved booklets in this activity.
and retold the story from the beginning to the end, using lots of descriptive words.
We are going to tell our own story today. Look at these objects. Imagine what is happening. We will add to the story until we have a beginning, a middle, and an end. I’ll start.
Once upon a time, there was a
and point to the child to your right. You will likely need to keep children from wandering off topic, or help them with ideas to start.
Repeat until each child has a turn. You may need to tell children,
We’ve set a beginning (or middle); let’s move on to the middle (or end).
After the story is complete, write it on a board or paper that can be displayed. Once it has been written, read it aloud. Assign each child one part of the story and collect each page.
Use the sleeved booklet to compile children’s story pages. Ask:
What happened in the beginning of our story? The middle? The end?

Children may struggle to differentiate between the beginning, middle, and end of a story. If so, turn to more familiar examples—folk and fairy tales, for example—before starting the activity. Discuss the different parts of the plot using those stories.
For children who would welcome a challenge, allow them to create their own story about the set-up with a beginning, middle, and end. They can tell it orally, or write it using words or pictures.
Review common verbs with multilingual learners such as
run, jump, dance, fly, sing, read,
Make a list or draw common verbs so children can refer to them as they create their stories.

If children struggle to sit long enough to tell an entire story, assign them a job. For example: they can move the toys to go along with the action being described in the story. Assigning responsibility helps keep children focused on a specific activity. Their success provides an opportunity for positive feedback.

Today we talked about a boy who learned to race even though he couldn’t run. We learned about all the things the boy did to prepare for the race.

Now it’s our turn! We are going to have a race of our own! I’m going to show an alphabet letter. Your job is to write the letter that comes after the letter I show you. Let’s practice this race together.
What letter comes next? I’m going to write the letter
Place trays of salt in front of each child. Instruct children to not touch the salt until you hold up the Alphabet Card.
Ask children if they are ready to begin. Tell them that whoever writes the letter in the salt first will win the round. Show the V Alphabet Card.
Have children write the letter they think comes next. Stop the round once a child has written the letter
Repeat the round by showing the letter
Show as many letters as you can to keep children engaged.
Encourage children to talk about how they felt during alphabet racing.
How did you know what letter to write in the salt? How did it feel to race each other? What if I told you to write the next number after 9? What would have you written?
Ask children if they liked this activity and if they would change anything about it.
Instead of writing the next consecutive letter, have children write the letter they see on the Alphabet Card. For example, if you show the Y Alphabet Card, have children write the letter

For children who may find this activity less challenging, show an object or say a word and have children write the letter the word starts with. Switch up the variation of the race and have the winner lead the next round by saying a word or showing an object.

Be aware that multilingual learners may be thinking of the alphabet in their first language instead of the English alphabet. Before you start the race, have children sing the alphabet song together. Ensure all children have a clear understanding of the English alphabet before starting the race.

Be aware that competitive activities may upset children and monitor how children are feeling during the races. Be prepared to end the races early or allow children to simply write the letters together without competing against each other.
